document.masterDocTitle: Mortonagrion indraneil spec. nov. from Borneo, and a redescription of M. arthuri Fraser (Odonata: Zygoptera: Coenagrionidae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Mortonagrion indraneil spec. nov. from Borneo, and a redescription of M. arthuri Fraser (Odonata: Zygoptera: Coenagrionidae)

heading.emphasis:
Relationship of
Mortonagrion
with
Agriocnemis
and
Argiocnemis

subSubSection.paragraph:
Mortonagrion
has had a confused history since it was erected. A number of species have at various times been placed in
Mortonagrion
, and at other times placed in the allied genera
Agriocnemis
and
Argiocnemis
. The issue of the relationships among these genera has never been satisfactorily resolved, for instance see
Pinhey ( 1974 )
and
Hämäläinen ( 1989 )
. Until now the sole character that has been considered to reliably distinguish
Mortonagrion
from
Agriocnemis
and
Argiocnemis
is a detail of wing venation: “ ab continued on as
1 a in the same straight line, no angulated medio-anal link intervening at the junction
” (
Fraser 1933 : 409
). The species currently placed in
Mortonagrion
, excluding
M. aborense
and
M. alcyone
and the African
M. stygia Fraser, 1954
, share a number of other characteristics, for instance: complicated postocular markings in the males, mesostigmal plates strongly raised up along one or more edges in females (e.g.
Figs 8–10
) and triangular paraprocts (e.g.
Fig. 32
) in females (rather than the rather formless paraprocts typical in the Coenagrionidae ). These species certainly appear to be more closely related to each other than to any other species, but none of the characters mentioned is unique to this group of species, all being found in some species typically placed in
Agriocnemis
.

M. aborense
and
M. alcyone
both share some characters with
Argiocnemis rubescens Selys, 1877
, the genotype of
Argiocnemis
, that are not shared with the other
Mortonagrion
species: all have simple postocular markings, relatively simple broad triangular mesostigmal plates and formless paraprocts in the female, and very similar male anal appendages; they also share a typical scheme of colour changes from immaturity to maturity. See
Hämäläinen ( 1989 )
for a summary of the complicated history of
A. aborense
; however it differs significantly in genital ligula structure from all other species examined or for which illustrations were available from all three genera (see below).
A. alcyone
appears to have become associated with Mortanagrion almost by accident, as it does not even consistently share the venational character, for instance the lectotype male in the BMNH has an angulated medioanal link joining ab with 1 A.

M. stygia
has mature colouration more typical of many
Agriocnemis
species, but the female variably has triangular paraprocts. The genital ligula is of
Agriocnemis
/
Mortonagrion
form (see below). It is difficult to come to any firm conclusion on the placement of this species at the moment.

Probably the most promising character to distinguish
Argiocnemis
from
Agriocnemis
and
Mortonagrion
, and possibly the latter two genera from each other, is the structure of the genital ligula. The genital ligula of
Agriocnemis femina (Brauer, 1868 )
(
Fig. 25
),
Argiocnemis rubescens rubeola
(
Fig. 26
),
Argiocnemis
sp. (
Fig. 27
; a problematic form distinct from, but possibly with a name buried in the synonymy of,
A. rubescens
),
Mortonagrion aborense
(
Fig. 28
),
M. alcyone
(
Fig. 29
),
M. arthuri
(
Fig. 30
) and
M. indraneil
(
Fig. 31
) were examined by Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM). With the exception of
M. aborense
, the genital ligula of all the species examined is broadly similar; the terminal segment has simple-shaped broad apical lateral lobes, at rest directed back on either side of the shaft. In
Mortonagrion
and
Argiocnemis
there are rows of short setae or spines dorsolaterally on either side of the shaft; in
Agriocnemis femina
the spines are absent from the shaft, but there is a small clump of spines on each side of the segment that lies between the apical lobes of the terminal segment. In
Argiocnemis rubescens
,
Argiocnemis
sp. and
M. alcyone
the terminal part of the lateral lobes has a fringe of narrow teeth along its margin, but these teeth are absent in the other species examined.
Pinhey ( 1974 )
illustrated the genital ligula of all African species known to him, including
M. stygia
, and
Agriocnemis pygmaea (Rambur, 1842 )
which is also widely distributed in Asia; the genital ligula of all of these species is of the general
Agriocnemis
/
Mortonagrion
form. However with the equipment available to him Pinhey may not have been able to see certain features of the genital ligula, such as spines or setae, but it seems likely that a fringe of teeth such as occurs in
M. alcyone
,
Argiocnemis rubescens
and
Argiocnemis
sp. would have been visible to him; presumably no such fringe occurs in any of the species examined by Pinhey. As noted by
Pinhey ( 1974
: 271 as
M. simile Ris, 1930
) and illustrated by
Asahina ( 1982
: 457 ,
Figs 9–10
as
M. binocellata Fraser, 1922
) the genital ligula of
M. aborense
(
Fig. 28
) is of a different form from all the other species considered, with, as Pinhey puts it “flagella united into a single short, broad scoop over the stem.”

I consider the placement of
aborense
and
alcyone
in
Mortonagrion
to be extremely doubtful, with
alcyone
belonging with the
Argiocnemis
species which it closely resembles and
aborense
possibly deserving its own genus. However in order to prevent further confusion it appears best to leave the status of these species unchanged at this time.
Mortonagrion
may itself prove to be merely a specialised group within
Agriocnemis
, but this should be considered as part of a full review of the relationships between
Mortonagrion , Agriocnemis
and
Argiocnemis
; such a review is a major undertaking that must include the African as well as Asian species, SEM studies of the genital ligula and molecular studies. A final resolution of this issue will not be based on characters of wing venation.
